comments:
Application of statics and dynamics to simple force analyses of the
musculoskeletal system. Introduction to the fundamentals of strength of materials.
Biomechanics of soft and hard tissues: microstructure and mechanical properties. This
course is intended to provide a solid foundation in statics and mechanics of materials with
particular focus on human joint biomechanics. The first portion of the course presents
fundamental concepts of force and mechanics of rigid and deformable bodies. The
remainder of the course consists of an introduction of materials science and engineering,
including the classification and bulk properties of implantable materials, and also
addresses specific topics including torsional loading and bending. By the end of the
course, it is anticipated that students are able to integrate the origin of tissue mechanical
properties with structure/function analyses of load-bearing tissues in the human body.
Students generally found this class to be “well-organized”, “fair”, and
“enjoyable.” While students reported that both the mechanics and the materials portions
were well-explained, they felt that there was little connection between the two sections.
The homework assignments prepared the students for the exams, which required a good
grasp of algebra and physics. Quite a few students found the textbook for the mechanics
section to be redundant.
Professor Dourte was described as an engaging instructor. Students found her
notes to be much more helpful in explaining mechanics concepts than the textbook.
Students described the weekly homework assignments as “challenging but feasible.” The
work usually took about 4 to 8 hours to finish. The exams were reasonable as long as
students completed homework. This class is recommended for Bioengineering majors
only.
